Any test done?
The code was tested and no problems found.
Done

This commit replaces the debus-remove.patch from:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/65557
(since patches are not supported in openbmc/openbmc layer)

This commit is to be used with https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/65556 that relies on udev events of driver loading to start a systemd service. The service will then parse EEPROM data and update the inventory.
The implicit request was to list the tests here.
Yes, please add description on tests have been done and the tests result. So reviewer can see that the code change works as expected without breaking things.
Patrick will have to edit the commit message with his details about his testing.
Done
This can be the title.
Done
In principle this is reasonable. In practice, what is the use case, hot-pluggable items?

Not only hot-pluggable items, but pluggable items.

When any FRU device (that does not have a IPMI compatible FRU EERPROM) is replaced when the host is off the drivers will still hold the cached information.
For EEPROM like devices, as the driver isn't unloaded, it will keep advertising the cached information to userspace.
Agree with the risk here. I am concerned that this change will cause services to crash in people's systems.
Using drivers on top of hardware that has been removed or have been powered off doesn't seem to be a good alternative.

Not disagree with this. But it has been the way the code is running. My concern is that this would break some services that are not designed to handle drives gets unloaded unexpectedly. In reality i don't how we can identify these, if any, services need to be fixed before making this change.

This is almost identical to block 291-295, then can be combined
linkOrUnlinkMux(name, *bus, *address, *channels, expose);
Done
